chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management
chapter.summary: Cover the management and referral of children and adults with IgE-mediated food allergy in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a person has a suspected food allergy:

  • Arrange immediate ambulance transfer to Accident and Emergency if:
    • There are systemic symptoms or suspected anaphylaxis with or without angio-oedema. See the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis for more information on emergency management.
  • Arrange referral to an allergy specialist for further assessment and management, the urgency depending on clinical judgement, if:
    • The person has had one or more episodes of systemic symptoms consistent with a severe reaction. See the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis for more information.
    • The person is at increased risk of anaphylaxis, such as a history of food allergy and co-morbid persistent or poorly controlled asthma; or a severe reaction to a trace amount of food allergen (airborne, or contact through skin only). See the CKS topic on Asthma for more information.
    • Allergy testing is needed to confirm the diagnosis, or to assess whether tolerance has developed to a specific food allergen, depending on local referral pathways and availability.
    • The diagnosis is uncertain.
    • There are multiple suspected food allergies.
    • There is significant atopic eczema, where multiple or cross-reactive food allergies are suspected. See the CKS topic on Eczema - atopic for more information.
    • There is persistent food allergy beyond the age of expected tolerance, or adult-onset allergy.
    • There is persistent parental or carer suspicion of food allergy (particularly if there are difficult or perplexing symptoms) despite a lack of supporting history, or persistent anxiety about the diagnosis of food allergy.
  • Arrange referral to a paediatric dietitian or dietitian if:
    • There are concerns about faltering growth, excessive weight gain, nutritional status, or inappropriate dietary restriction — advice on replacement foods or supplements can be given.
    • Advice on specific food allergen avoidance is needed.
    • Advice on food reintroduction is needed — tolerance often develops in steps, with cooked forms tolerated before raw equivalents. For egg allergy, a ladder system may be used which involves starting with well-cooked and baked foods (such as cake), and working up through foods with lessening degrees of heating (such as scrambled egg).
    • The person is already on a restricted diet for other reasons, which may be cultural or religious.

Allergy testing may involve initial skin prick testing or measuring serum-specific immunoglobulin (Ig)E levels to different food allergens, and should be undertaken by healthcare professionals with the appropriate facilities, expertise, and training to select and perform tests, and interpret results.

  • Skin prick testing involves the epicutaneous introduction of allergen extracts with a lancet, typically to the volar aspect of the forearm. The site is inspected after 15 minutes and compared with positive and negative controls (observer dependent), to detect sensitization to allergens.
  • Serum-specific IgE testing is widely available, but results are not immediate and may take days to weeks to process.
  • Both allergy tests are sensitive but not specific, and have various limitations and potential difficulties in interpretation:
    • Skin prick test sensitization may be suppressed by recent antihistamine, beta-blocker, tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), and topical corticosteroid use.
      • Serum-specific IgE testing may be more appropriate when skin prick testing is not possible, or when skin prick testing taken with the clinical history give equivocal results.
    • Allergy testing cannot distinguish between sensitization and true allergy, so test results must be interpreted in the context of the clinical history.
      • Some people have positive test results but do not develop symptoms of clinical allergy on exposure to the relevant food allergen (food sensitization only and a false positive result).
      • Due to the poor specificity of tests, indiscriminately testing for large panels of food allergens is not recommended as there is a high false positive rate.
      • Some people may have a strong clinical history of IgE-mediated food allergy but negative allergy test results (false negative result).
    • Increased size of the skin prick wheal or concentrations of serum-specific IgE are associated with an increased likelihood of food allergy, but they do not predict symptom severity.
      • Ideally raw foods should be used in skin prick testing for the assessment of suspected oral allergy syndrome.
    • Note: atopy patch testing is not recommended for the routine assessment of suspected food allergy.
  • Allergy testing may also be used to assess whether tolerance has developed in a person with a confirmed food allergy. The optimal interval for follow-up testing is not known, and partly depends on the specific food allergen:
    • For egg, soybean, or wheat allergy, testing every 12–18 months up to the age of 5 years, and every 2–3 years following this, may be recommended.
    • For peanut, tree nut, fish, and shellfish allergy, testing every 2–4 years may be recommended.
  • If the results of allergy testing do not correspond with the clinical history, an oral food challenge may be needed to confirm the diagnosis:
    • Oral food challenge is the gold standard for diagnosis of food allergy, and is an accurate and sensitive test. It involves the administration of increasing quantities of the food allergen under medical supervision, starting with direct mucosal exposure (allergen contact with the lips) and then titrated oral ingestion as tolerated. If symptoms are not provoked, the test is negative and clinical allergy can be excluded.
    • If there has been a previous severe reaction to a known food, a repeat challenge is not usually arranged for at least two years.

[RCPCH, 2011; Burks, 2012; Longo, 2013; Steele, 2014; Turnbull, 2015; Stiefel, 2017; NICE, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on referral of a person with suspected food allergy are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Food allergy in under 19s: assessment and diagnosis [NICE, 2018], the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (RCPCH) publication Allergy Care Pathways for Children. Food allergy [RCPCH, 2011]; the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) Guidelines for the management of egg allergy [Clark, 2010] and Guideline for the diagnosis and management of peanut and tree nut allergy [Stiefel, 2017]; the International Collaboration in Asthma, Allergy and Immunology consensus document ICON: Food allergy [Burks, 2012], the US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of food allergy in the United States [Boyce, 2010], the Resuscitation Council (UK) guideline Emergency treatment of anaphylactic reactions: guidelines for healthcare providers [Resuscitation Council (UK), 2012], and expert opinion in review articles on food allergy [Longo, 2013; Steele, 2014; Turnbull, 2015; Meyer, 2018].

Emergency management of suspected anaphylaxis
  • The recommendation on arranging emergency transfer to hospital for suspected anaphylaxis is based on the Resuscitation Council (UK) guidelines [Resuscitation Council (UK), 2012].
Arranging referral to an allergy specialist
  • The recommendations on who to refer to an allergy clinic are largely based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], the BSACI guidelines on egg allergy [Clark, 2010], and expert opinion in review articles [Longo, 2013; Steele, 2014].
    • The NICE clinical guideline found low-quality evidence to guide recommendations on referral, and also used a consensus approach to make its recommendations.
    • The information on people who may be at increased risk of anaphylaxis is based on the BSACI guidelines, the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in a review article [Longo, 2013].
    • The recommendation that referral to an allergy clinic may be needed for allergy testing is based on the NICE clinical guideline, which states that tests should be performed in the appropriate setting with appropriate skills for the interpretation of test results. The RCPCH publication states that resolution of food allergy (tolerance) should be assessed by allergy testing and, if indicated, rechallenge. This approach is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Steele, 2014].
      • The BSACI guidelines on egg allergy state that food reintroduction may be done at home if reactions have been mild and there is no history of asthma, and this approach is supported by the RCPCH publication. Conversely, if there is a history of severe allergic reaction, food reintroduction should be guided by an allergy specialist.
    • The recommendation to refer if there is an uncertain diagnosis is based on the fact that additional immunological studies or endoscopy and biopsy may be needed, following specialist assessment [RCPCH, 2011; Burks, 2012].
    • The recommendation to refer if there are multiple suspected food allergies is based on the NICE clinical guideline, based on consensus opinion.
    • The recommendation to refer if there is significant atopic eczema and complex food allergies are suspected, is based on the NICE clinical guideline and the BSACI guidelines on egg allergy.
    • The recommendation to refer if there is persistent or adult-onset allergy is based on the BSACI guidelines on egg allergy and expert opinion in a review article [Steele, 2014].
    • The recommendation to refer if there is significant parental or carer concern is based on the NICE clinical guideline and the RCPCH publication, which states that management of more complex cases may involve the multidisciplinary team such as a clinical nurse specialist in paediatric allergy and additional psychosocial support, if needed.
Arranging referral to a dietitian
  • The recommendations on when to refer to a dietitian are based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guidelines [Clark, 2010; Stiefel, 2017], and expert opinion in review articles [Steele, 2014; Turnbull, 2015; Meyer, 2018].
    • Dietitians can advise on the safety and proposed duration of exclusion and elimination diets [Meyer, 2018; NICE, 2018].
    • Inappropriate or unnecessary dietary restriction can increase the risk of nutritional deficiencies and anxiety of the person or parent/carer [Steele, 2014; Meyer, 2018].
    • The benefits of allowing cooked products into the diet as soon as they are tolerated include improved quality of life, improved nutritional status, and potentially faster development of tolerance to food allergens [Turnbull, 2015].
    • The information on the use of the egg ladder to reintroduce egg into the diet is based on expert opinion in a review article [Turnbull, 2015] and the expert opinion of an external reviewer of this CKS topic.
    • The recommendation that referral may be needed if a person is already on a restricted diet is based on the BSACI guideline on egg allergy [Clark, 2010].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Self-management and follow-up
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Ensure a person with a confirmed diagnosis of food allergy has an individualized written allergy management plan, taking into account the specific food allergen, the person's age, co-morbidities, and nutritional status.

  • Provide advice on sources of information and support, such as:
    • The Allergy UK factsheets on Childhood food allergy, Types of food allergy (covers multiple different specific food allergies), and Managing my food allergy.
    • British Dietetic Association patient leaflets Food allergies and intolerances, Coping with food allergies, and Food allergy and intolerance testing.
    • The patient information leaflets Food allergy and intolerance, Nut allergy, and Oral allergy syndrome available on the www.patient.info website.
    • The British Association of Dermatologists' patient leaflet Latex allergy.
  • Provide written advice on prompt recognition and management of acute symptoms following accidental or new exposures, for example using a British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) Allergy Action Plan. If the person has:
    • A history of anaphylaxis or a suspected acute systemic reaction — see the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis for more information on emergency management.
    • Mild or moderate symptoms — advise on the immediate use of an oral non-sedating antihistamine such as cetirizine or loratadine, to be taken 'as-needed'. In infants and children aged less than two years the sedating antihistamine chlorphenamine may be used instead.
      • See the section on Oral antihistamines in Prescribing information for more information on licensed doses, cautions and contraindications, adverse effects, and drug interactions.
    • Oral allergy syndrome — advise on the additional management of co-morbid allergic rhinitis symptoms. See the CKS topic on Allergic rhinitis for more information.
  • Provide advice and education on food allergen avoidance, to help the person make safe and appropriate food choices, which may include:
    • Which foods and drinks to avoid, including foods that may be cross-reactive and which foods are suitable alternatives.
      • Confirmed allergy to a specific tree nut or shellfish may require avoidance of all food allergens in these classes, unless they are known to be tolerant or have had negative allergy tests.
      • This includes advice on baked or processed forms of the food.
    • How to check and interpret food labels and recognise food allergens in ingredients lists of food products.
      • This includes lists of alternative terms for specific food allergens (such as ovalbumin or ovomucoid for egg) and advice on precautionary allergen labelling, such as 'may contain' or 'not suitable for' statements.
      • Advise that loose foods (for example bought from markets or open bakeries) and foods imported from outside the EU, may not have food ingredient labelling, and may be best avoided.
    • Awareness of possible cross-contamination of foods with allergens during food manufacture, preparation, and serving.
    • Awareness of situations when accidental exposure is more likely, such as in nursery/school, when eating out, birthday parties, friends' houses, or when travelling.
      • It is important to liaise with nursery or school to update them if the person's allergy management plan changes over time.
      • It may be helpful to wipe eating surfaces before meals, to reduce the risk of cross-contamination, especially when eating out of the home environment.
    • Information that peeled raw trigger food(s) in cases of mild oral allergy syndrome may reduce any subsequent reaction.
  • Provide advice about allergen avoidance during travel, including air travel and travelling abroad.
    • Inform the airline before a flight, and ensure cabin staff are aware of the food allergy on the day of travel.
    • It may be helpful to wipe eating surfaces before meals, to reduce the risk of cross-contamination.
    • Emergency medication should be carried in the aircraft cabin or train carriage within easy reach.
    • The Allergy UK factsheet Travelling with allergy may be helpful.
  • Provide advice on the impact (if any) of the food allergy on vaccinations. See the CKS topics on Immunizations - childhood and Immunizations - seasonal influenza for more information on people with egg allergy.
  • Ensure that co-morbid conditions such as asthma are optimally managed in primary care. See the CKS topic on Asthma for more information.
  • Ensure that the person is reviewed by a specialist or in primary care at least annually, to:
    • Review symptoms, any accidental exposures or reactions.
    • Assess for any new-onset food allergies.
    • Assess the person's dietary intake and nutritional status.
    • Reinforce the importance of allergen avoidance strategies.
    • Check for the development of new co-morbidities such as asthma or eczema, whether symptoms are controlled, and the risk of anaphylaxis. See the CKS topics on Asthma and Eczema - atopic for more information.
    • Arrange specialist allergy clinic referral, for example for repeat allergy testing to assess whether tolerance has developed to a specific food allergen, depending on local referral pathways and availability.
    • Arrange dietitian referral for monitoring of growth and nutrition, or advice on food reintroduction, if needed.
    • Update the individualized written allergy management plan, as appropriate.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on self-management strategies are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Food allergy in under 19s: assessment and diagnosis [NICE, 2018], the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (RCPCH) publication Allergy Care Pathways for Children. Food allergy [RCPCH, 2011], the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (EAACI) Food allergy and anaphylaxis guidelines: managing patients with food allergy in the community [Muraro, 2014]; the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) Guidelines for the management of egg allergy [Clark, 2010] and Guideline for the diagnosis and management of peanut and tree nut allergy [Stiefel, 2017]; the International Collaboration in Asthma, Allergy and Immunology consensus document ICON: Food allergy [Burks, 2012], the US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of food allergy in the United States [Boyce, 2010], a systematic review on the management of food allergy [de Silva, 2014], and expert opinion in review articles on food allergy [Longo, 2013; Steele, 2014; Anagnostou, 2015; Turnbull, 2015].

Advice on sources of information and support
  • This recommendation is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018] and the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011].
  • The information on free-from product finder apps is based on the expert opinion of an external reviewer of this CKS topic.
Providing a written personal management plan
  • This recommendation is based on the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], the BSACI guidelines [Clark, 2010; Stiefel, 2017], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], the ICON consensus document [Burks, 2012], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in review articles [Steele, 2014; Turnbull, 2015].
    • The EAACI guidelines note that the use of individualized emergency management plans for food allergy are associated with a decreasing incidence of severe allergic reactions following their use.
    • The ICON consensus document states that having an emergency action plan may promote empowerment and improve health outcomes.
Management of acute symptoms
  • The recommendations on acute management of non-severe reactions with an oral antihistamine are based on the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], the BSACI guidelines [Clark, 2010; Stiefel, 2017], the ICON consensus document [Burks, 2012], a systematic review [de Silva, 2014], and expert opinion in review articles [Longo, 2013; Steele, 2014].
    • The systematic review found weak evidence from three randomized and two non-randomized comparisons, that oral antihistamines provide some benefit in relieving immediate, non-life-threatening symptoms in children and adults with food allergy.
Advice on food avoidance
  • The recommendations on food avoidance are largely based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], the EAACI [Muraro, 2014] and BSACI guidelines [Clark, 2010; Stiefel, 2017], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], a systematic review [de Silva, 2014], and expert opinion in review articles [Longo, 2013; Turnbull, 2015].
    • The recommendation to avoid all foods that are potentially cross-reactive in the same food class is based on the BSACI guideline on peanut and tree nut allergy, and expert opinion in a review article [Longo, 2013].
    • The recommendations on precautionary allergen labelling are based on the BSACI guideline on peanut and tree nut allergy and the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010].
    • The information to liaise with nursery and school regarding any changes to the allergy management plan is based on the EAACI and BSACI guidelines.
    • The information that peeled raw trigger foods may be helpful in cases of mild oral allergy syndrome is based on expert opinion in a review article that many immunogenic proteins are found within fruit and vegetable skins [Turnbull, 2015].
Advice on travelling
  • The recommendations to ensure allergen avoidance while travelling are based on expert opinion in the EAACI guideline [Muraro, 2014] and in a review article [Anagnostou, 2015].
Advice on vaccinations
  • This recommendation is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018] and the BSACI guidelines on egg allergy [Clark, 2010].
    • All children with egg allergy should receive the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine, but specialist allergy assessment or alternative ovalbumin-free influenza vaccine may be indicated for specific people, depending on the age of the person and severity of previous allergic reaction to egg [Clark, 2010].
Management of co-morbid conditions
  • This recommendation is based on the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], the EAACI [Muraro, 2014] and BSACI guidelines [Clark, 2010; Stiefel, 2017].
Arranging regular review
  • The recommendation on arranging regular review is based on the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], the EAACI [Muraro, 2014] and BSACI guidelines [Clark, 2010; Stiefel, 2017], the ICON consensus document [Burks, 2012], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in a review article [Longo, 2013].
  • The recommendation to consider dietitian referral is based on the fact they may provide advice on alternative sources of nutrition to ensure adequate nutritional intake [NICE, 2018], and it is also extrapolated from the RCPCH publication which states that nutritional support and monitoring by a dietitian should be part of standard management of food allergy [RCPCH, 2011].
